metadata.case_name: Rajvi Amarsingh v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Appellant appointed as District and Sessions Judge in former Bikaner State on January 29, 1948, in grade Rs. 500-40-700, worked till April 7, 1949.

New State of Rajasthan formed on April 7, 1949, by integration of States including Bikaner via Covenant; Article XVI guarantees continuance in service on not less advantageous conditions than on November 1, 1948, or compensation or proportionate pension.
On December 9, 1949, Rajasthan Government transferred appellant as District and Sessions Judge, Churu to Ganganagar.

Rajasthan Gazette Notification dated May 25, 1950, made provisional ad hoc postings of judicial officers; appellant posted as Civil and Additional Sessions Judge in Jaipur Division; stated as without prejudice to creation of Judicial Service.
Increment of Rs. 40 sanctioned on July 31, 1950 (effect from March 23, 1950), describing appellant as District and Sessions Judge in Bikaner Division, raising salary from Rs. 540 to Rs. 580.

Appellant made representation on September 11, 1950, against ad hoc posting as Civil and Additional Sessions Judge; understood as without prejudice to permanent claims; allegation admitted by opposite party.

Appellant appointed substantively as Civil Judge on April 23, 1951, placed in Group C (Civil Judges and Munsiffs) at No. 18; pay and emoluments unchanged (Rs. 500-40-700), earned increments unaffected.
Appellant filed writ petition on April 3, 1954, claiming entitlement to District and Sessions Judge post under Covenant, alleging reduction in rank without opportunity under Art. 311.

Rajasthan High Court by judgment dated September 5, 1955, held April 23, 1951 appointment as ad hoc, directed Government to provide machinery per Constitution for first recruitment to Rajasthan Judicial Service.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on April 16, 1956.
Post High Court order, Rajasthan Government reframed rules, made fresh appointments published in Gazette; appellant selected and appointed as Civil Judge.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appointments post-integration constituted a reduction in rank without opportunity to show cause, violating Article 311 of the Constitution.
Effect of Article XVI of the Covenant on continuance of service and conditions post-integration.
Whether old contracts of service terminate upon State integration, allowing new State to impose fresh terms.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to posting as District and Sessions Judge under guarantee in Article XVI of Covenant; December 9, 1949 transfer and increment sanctions indicate election to continue in original post; April 23, 1951 posting reduces rank without opportunity, violating Art. 311.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article XVI of Covenant; Article 311 of Constitution

petitioner_arguments.text: Ad hoc postings without prejudice to permanent claims; fresh appointment post High Court also bad under Art. 311.

respondent_arguments.text: Post-integration, old contracts terminate; new service on terms imposed by new State; no reduction in rank as prior postings temporary/transitional; conditions not less advantageous.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Principles from precedents on change of sovereignty

court_reasoning.text: Upon State integration, old service contracts terminate; servants serve on new terms chosen by new State, per settled law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Application of master-servant principle on change of masters.

court_reasoning.text: Article XVI provides options (continuance, compensation, pension), indicating termination of old contracts and fresh ones; guarantees only not less advantageous conditions than Nov 1, 1948, which were fulfilled (pay unchanged).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No guarantee of same post or better conditions.

court_reasoning.text: December 9, 1949 transfer, May 25, 1950 ad hoc posting, increment sanctions were temporary transitional arrangements pending final reorganisation; no permanent posting implied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reduction in rank from temporary to substantive as prior were ad hoc.

court_reasoning.text: April 23, 1951 appointment (struck down as ad hoc by High Court) or subsequent one is first substantive; Art. 311 not attracted.

holdings.text: Old contracts terminate on integration; new State may impose fresh terms; no reduction in rank, Art. 311 inapplicable.
Article XVI guarantees only not less advantageous conditions, not same post.
Prior postings temporary; first substantive appointment post-reorganisation.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. K. M. Rajagopalan
precedents_cited.relevance: Old contracts terminate on State absorption/integration; fresh terms by new State.
Supports principle on termination of contracts on change of sovereignty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nokes v. Doncaster Amalgamated Collieries Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Supports principle on termination of contracts on change of sovereignty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Virendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between property rights and contractual rights on change of sovereignty.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ mandamus; protection against reduction in rank without show cause.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; held no reduction in rank or Art. 311 violation as old contracts terminated on integration, prior postings temporary, conditions not less advantageous; Covenant guarantee fulfilled.

key_quotes.text: "when one State is absorbed in another... all contracts of service between the prior Government and its servants automatically terminate and thereafter those who elect to serve in the new State... serve on such terms and conditions as the new State may choose to impose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on termination of service contracts post-integration.

key_quotes.text: "The only guarantee... was that the new conditions were not to be less advantageous than those on which the appellant was serving on November 1, 1948. There was no guarantee that they would be the same or better."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation limiting Article XVI of Covenant.
